text: don't be fooled just because people talk
in the garb of science
the web is filled with what we might
call counter knowledge that is a whole
bunch of stuff that isn't true
that's bathed in the wording and the
phraseology of science and medicine and
so it makes you think it's true years
ago if you saw something in a book in a
library it was a pretty good bet that it
had been authenticated you could still
read nonsense but it was far less likely
even today we're on the internet a real
valid claim is almost indistinguishable
from an invalid claim or a hoax because
of the ability of just anybody to go and
make a webpage that looks pretty
sophisticated so there are all these
terms being thrown around that make you
think the person knows what he or she is
talking about but just by using those
words doesn't actually prove that the
person's an expert they have to actually
be scientists and if they are they'll
typically tell you the mechanisms by
which things work if you're looking at a
scientific claim made by a scientist in
most cases it will have been
peer-reviewed meaning other scientists
not related to the study will have
looked at it and agreed that the methods
were proper that's really the gold
standard for a claim if you just hear
somebody on the web or on the radio
saying that they did the experiment
themselves it's not published that's a
pretty good clue that there might be
something off about it there's this term
alternative medicine and that itself is
kind of a weird term there's medicine
which has been shown to work and then
anything that hasn't been shown to work
and there's no evidence for we call
alternative medicine as soon as we have
evidence that it's working it's just
plain old medicine but it's easier for a
lie to take hold and be distributed
across millions of people you have to
probe a little deeper and see who it is
that created it what biases might they
have
is it a hoax and there are now
thankfully a number of sites
sort that out like snopes.com and
PolitiFact
